citation.article-title: Pedobacter insulae sp. nov., isolated from soil
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Pedobacter insulae sp. nov.
Pedobacter insulae (in.su′lae. L. fem. gen. n. insulae of an island, referring to the source of isolation of the type strain).
Cells are Gram-negative, non-spore-forming, non-flagellated rods (0.3–0.5×0.7–6.0 μm); occasionally cells greater than 10.0 μm in length occur.
Colonies on TSA are circular, convex, smooth, glistening, light yellow in colour and 1.0–2.0 mm in diameter after incubation for 7 days at 25 °C.
Optimal growth occurs at 25 °C; growth occurs at 4 and 31 °C, but not at 32 °C.
The optimal pH for growth is 6.5–7.5; growth occurs at pH 6.0 and 10.0, but not at pH 5.5 or 10.5.
Optimal growth occurs in the presence of 0–0.5 % (w/v) NaCl; growth does not occur in the presence of more than 2 % (w/v) NaCl.
Growth does not occur under anaerobic conditions on TSA or on TSA supplemented with nitrate.
Starch, tyrosine and Tweens 20, 40, 60 and 80 are hydrolysed, but casein, gelatin, hypoxanthine and xanthine are not.
Susceptible to carbenicillin, cephalothin, gentamicin, lincomycin, novobiocin, oleandomycin and streptomycin, but not to neomycin or polymyxin B.
The major fatty acids (>10 % of total fatty acids) are iso-C15 : 0, C16 : 1ω7c and/or iso-C15 : 0 2-OH and iso-C17 : 0 3-OH.
The DNA G+C content is 39.4 mol% (HPLC).

The type strain, DS-139T (=KCTC 12820T =DSM 18684T), was isolated from a soil at Dokdo, an island in Korea.
